headline: Kobbie Mainoo offered Man Utd escape route with ex-teammate involved in Napoli transfer plan
body: Napoli are willing to cover all of Kobbie Mainoo's wages in the hope of signing him in the January transfer window. The Italian champions are desperate to lure the Manchester United outcast to Naples as soon as possible.

Napoli president Aurelio De Laurentiis has told United he is prepared to honour Mainoo's £35,000-a-week contract. De Laurentiis has spoken to Napoli stars Kevin De Bruyne and Scott McTominay about Mainoo - and the duo have told him the England midfielder would be a great signing for Antonio Conte's side.

Napoli tried to sign Mainoo in the summer, but he decided to remain at United when Ruben Amorim told him he wanted to keep him. But Mainoo has remained on the fringes of Amorim's team and has made just eight appearances in all competitions this season.

It's understood Napoli want to take Mainoo on an initial loan, with a view to making the deal permanent in the summer. Mainoo knows he will have to leave Old Trafford to secure regular starts, if he wants to stand a realistic chance of being included in England's squad for the 2026 World Cup.

Napoli have enjoyed success by signing unwanted United players, with McTominay being named the Serie A Player of the Season in their title-winning campaign. Rasmus Hojlund has also made a strong start since joining on loan in the summer, scoring four goals in seven games so far.

Mainoo fits into the same category as a frustrated player who is seeking regular game time. Coming into this weekend, the 20-year-old United academy graduate had started just one game for United this season, and that came in their disastrous defeat by Grimsby in the Carabao Cup.

He has been stuck as a substitute in the Premier League, with Amorim picking Casemiro and Bruno Fernandes in central midfield. Mainoo's exit was blocked on deadline day, with Amorim explaining in September what he expects from the youngster.

"I didn't have a conversation with him before the window closed because I didn't want Kobbie Mainoo thinking that I was having a conversation with him just to hold on to him," he said. "I did it this week.

"I believe in him a lot. He is a top player. But some of you think that Kobbie Mainoo is already done [a complete player]. I think he can do so much better. For some guys [talent] is enough, but for him it is not. Maybe it's not fair, but I think I'm helping Kobbie and that's it."

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo's three-word message to son after Portugal first speaks volumes
body: Cristiano Ronaldo has sent a three-word message to his son after he scored his first goal for Portugal's Under-16s in their 3–0 win over Wales on Saturday. The 15-year-old has enjoyed a remarkable week, taking another step towards following in his father's footsteps by making his debut for the U16s.

Portugal are competing in the Federations Cup Tournament between October 30 and November 4, facing Turkey, Wales, and England. Cristianinho's call-up marks a step up in age group, having made his debut for the U15s back in May.

He first featured in a 4–1 win over Japan and received congratulations from his father after making his international bow. The winger came off the bench for the U15s during the Vlatko Markovic international tournament in Croatia.
Fast forward a few months and Cristianinho has now made his U16s debut, coming on as a substitute in their 2–0 victory over Turkey.
The teenager, who plays for Al-Nassr's academy, scored Portugal's opener in the 42nd minute.
The goal prompted Manchester United legend, Ronaldo Sr to respond on Instagram, where he reposted the moment on his stories with a simple three-fire-emoji message.
The video, which circulated on social media, received a number of responses from fans.
One said: "Amazing goal by Cristiano Ronaldo Jr. for Portugal U16! Looks like the apple doesn’t fall far from the tree - future star in the making!"
A second added: "No pressure, just carrying one of the biggest names in football history. If he keeps working hard, the story writes itself."
Another continued: "Cristiano Jr. What a finish! Cristiano Ronaldo is building a monster, no one is ready for," while a fourth concluded: "He's definitely gonna do more than his father."

headline: Erik ten Hag's reaction after Man Utd agreed terms with Ruben Amorim BEFORE his sacking
body: Erik ten Hag was left stunned by his sacking at Manchester United, who'd already agreed terms with Ruben Amorim in secret. United decided to part ways with the Dutchman in the days leading up to his final match, a controversial 2-0 defeat away to West Ham.

Ten Hag, 55, had spent nearly two-and-a-half years in the Old Trafford hot seat, winning a trophy in both of his full seasons. But a lowly eighth-placed finish in the Premier League and poor recruitment ultimately cost the former Ajax boss his job.

Amorim, who was hot property thanks to his success at Sporting Lisbon, was the man chosen to replace him and has now been in charge for just under a year. As we approach the anniversary of his official appointment, the story of how he agreed to become United's manager has surfaced - and it's brutal for Ten Hag.

In the summer of 2024, Old Trafford chiefs privately spoke to different coaches about replacing him. After holding talks with Thomas Tuchel and Roberto De Zerbi, United's new-look hierarchy - headed up by Sir Jim Ratcliffe - opted to keep Ten Hag, triggering a one-year extension in his contract as a show of commitment.
But a poor start to his third season at the helm prompted Ratcliffe and Co to rethink. After going back to the drawing board, Amorim emerged as their top target and a meeting in Spain was set.

The Athletic report that by October 25, 2024, the Portuguese had agreed personal terms and said 'yes' in calls with Red Devils CEO Omar Berrada and soon-to-be director of football Jason Wilcox. That was all while United's players, Ten Hag and staff were travelling to London preparing to face West Ham.
Ten Hag's side were fresh off a 1-1 draw with Fenerbahce in Turkey, having beaten Brentford 2-1 at home the weekend prior. But United's bigwigs had already made their minds up.
Will Ruben Amorim have a more successful reign than Erik ten Hag? Give us your prediction in the comments section.
So when the Red Devils conceded a late penalty at the London Stadium, the axe was being sharped. On the Monday, October 28, Ten Hag was summoned to Carrington and informed of his sacking by Berrarda.
His reaction was one of shock. Ten Hag believed that he'd be given more time under the club's new leadership after proving that he could deliver silverware.

After deciding to wait until the beginning of the 2025-26 season to return to management, Ten Hag was appointed by Bayer Leverkusen, replacing the highly successful Xabi Alonso. His reign lasted just three games.

headline: Sean Dyche doesn't hold back as Man Utd get honest verdict amid Casemiro goal drama
body: Nottingham Forest manager Sean Dyche has fired back at the Premier League following their decision to allow Casemiro's opening goal for Manchester United to stand. Ruben Amorim's side took the lead in the 34th minute, after a dominant start at the City Ground, having been awarded a controversial corner.

Bruno Fernandes delivered the set-piece which led to Casemiro's header, but there were strong suggestions the corner should not have been given. Moments earlier, Nicola Savona appeared to deflect a dangerous cross and keep the ball in play, yet the assistant referee, positioned on the opposite side of the pitch, signalled for a corner.

"That's two decisions that aren't right that have gone against us. They give corners that aren't corners. They gave one last week and one this week. It's a really poor decision. That decides a lot. We are fighting for our lives to get up the table."
"From where I was standing, I was pretty far away, I didn't know if it went out. I haven't been able to check it yet, but all the boys were saying at half-time.

"The analysts, they said the ball had never gone out, so I think it's something that needs to be looked at because it happened twice to us now in two weeks. Last week against Bournemouth it wasn't their corner - so it's something they need to look at because it's cost us two points."
Forest remain winless in their last eight league games, while United are now unbeaten in their last four following wins against Sunderland, Liverpool and Brighton.

headline: Man Utd rescued by Amad stunner to derail dramatic Nottingham Forest comeback - 6 talking points
body: A quickfire double at the start of the second half saw Nottingham Forest come close to stunning Manchester United at the City Ground, only for Amad to volley home a stunning equaliser. United could have gone second in the Premier League with a win, but the point will still be a welcome sight for Ruben Amorim after his team trailed going into the final 10 minutes.

Morgan Gibbs-White and Nicolo Savona netted within the space of three minutes to turn the game on its head after Casemiro had given United a half-time lead. However, Amad lashed the ball beyond Matz Sels from the edge of the box and the goal was allowed to stand after a VAR check.

Casemiro had earlier been given the freedom of the City Ground to send a free header into the bottom corner from a Bruno Fernandes set piece. However, the start of the second half provided a reminder that things aren't quite as desperate as they seem for Forest or as positive as they once seemed for their opponents.

Bruno Fernandes fired against the foot of the post as United looked to bring themselves level, but Forest kept creating themselves. Igor Jesus was inches away from making it 3-1 with 25 minutes remaining and that might have been too much for the visitors to come back from.

Ruben Amorim's team went into the game chasing a fourth straight victory and started on the front foot. Benjamin Sesko has yet to hit top gear following his summer move but got an early sight of goal - with his effort deflected off-target - and showed some decent hold-up play in the early knockings.

Forest began to grow into the game, with Callum Hudson-Odoi offering a threat from out on the left and Elliot Anderson battling hard in the middle. They also squandered a promising opening when Nicolo Savona broke free down the right but got his final ball wrong, while United themselves continued to impress in flashes and Amad's deflected effort forced Matz Sels into a sharp stop.

After snatching a lead and going in ahead at the break, United, might have expected their struggling opponents to crumble. The opposite was true, though, with Forest showing the kind of fight they will need to survive.
Last weekend, Forest conceded against Bournemouth from a corner they don't believe should have been given. History repeated itself this week, though things weren't quite as cut and dried.

There was no doubt that a Bournemouth boot touched the ball last before Marcus Tavernier's Olimpico last time out. Here, the question concerned whether Savona was able to keep the ball from going behind, and plenty of outside observers agreed with Savona that play should have continued.

One thing that is for sure is that Forest should have got closer to Casemiro from the corner, just as they should have kept out Tavernier's effort at the Vitality Stadium. Set piece frailty is hardly the earmark of a Sean Dyche side, and he'll have reason to be annoyed.
Amad is unlikely to score many better goals than the one on Saturday. The Ivorian's connection was as sweet as they come, with Sels powerless as the ball nestled in the back of his net.

Forest's complaint will be about what came before.. The ball appeared to strike Patrick Dorgu on the arm as it spun up a few seconds before Amad struck, but neither the on-field referee nor the video assistant felt it was anough to disallow the goal.

That's two United goals which brought Forest complaints and they'll have to show spirit to put it all behind them. Amad won't mind, though, and it could be a vital moment for the Ivorian and his team.

If Savona was allowing himself to stew on that corner drama in the first half, he was soon over it. The Italian isn't known for his goals - he had just two in Serie A for Juventus last term - but sometimes quick reactions are all you need.

During Ange Postecoglou's brief tenure, Forest's players often looked lost and unable to form a united front. The period featured players looking unsure of their exact role, and the Italian was one of them.

New boss Dyche has long been a man who builds from the back, whether that's in the middle or in the full-back positions. Murillo and Nikola Milenkovic might look like the most obvious beneficiaries, but they're not the only ones.

It has taken a year, but Ruben Amorim at last named an unchanged Manchester United XI in the Premier League. He might feel he doesn't quite have the squad he needs to put his system into effect, but he at least has 11 players he is willing to trust to do it in back-to-back games..

That meant another start for Casemiro and a goal for the Brazilian. He might not be at his Real Madrid levels, or even the level he was in his first United season, but Amorim has found a way to use him.

“I think he gives a lot of experience. He's an example for everyone," Amorim recently said of Casemiro. “In the beginning, he was behind every midfielder, even Toby [Collyer], but he fought and he worked, and now he's back in the national team. He's so important for us.”

There was a moment in the first half when Senne Lammens was given the closest thing a goalkeeper can get to a hospital pass. The ball was pinged in his direction at pace by a United defender, but he calmly controlled the ball and continued as if it was no big deal.

He remained a composed figure for the remainder of the first half, and didn't give the impression he could have done much with Forest's goals. One thing's for certain, though, and that's that he appeared unruffled throughout.

United were reluctant to throw the Belgian in from the start after his arrival from Royal Antwerp, with suggestions they were worried about over-exposing him to the pressure of the role. On current evidence, though, he's exactly the right fit.

It feels like every week or two we're handed a definitive assessment of where Manchester United sit on the 'it's so over' to 'we're so back' scale. Sometimes we even get variations within the space of a single game, and it felt like today was one of those days.
As always, it can help to develop some perspective. The season doesn't end in November, and there's a long way to go from here for both United and Forest.

The challenge for managers is to block out the noise and get the message across to their players that things don't move as dramatically from one week to the next as some might have you believe. That is easier said than done, but any boss able to do just that is on to a winner.

headline: Why Casemiro goal shouldn't have stood as Man Utd get scathing new referee verdict
body: Casemiro's goal for Manchester United against Nottingham Forest has sparked controversy, with claims made it shouldn't have been allowed. After Ruben Amorim's side had dominated the first half-an-hour, they were then rewarded when the Brazilian international headed in a Bruno Fernandes corner, there are strong suggestions that the set-piece should not have been awarded.

Nicola Savona managed to deflect a threatening cross and seemed to have keep the ball in play, but the assistant referee, who was positioned on the opposite side of the pitch, signalled for a corner which Casemiro subsequently scored from.

Just over 10 minutes later, the home supporters let out a chorus of boos as the officials headed down the tunnel with chants of; 'You don't know what you're doing' following up. United were unlikely to be bothered, though, as they push a fourth straight victory in the Premier League.

Victories over Brighton, Liverpool and Sunderland came before the clash against Forest - with Bryan Mbeumo, Matheus Cunha and Casemiro proving clinical in front of goal. Playing once every seven days has, seemingly, assisted United and Amorim with another triumph on Saturday likely to take them into the top four, if only for a few hours.
Forest scored twice in quick succession upon the restart, though, to recover from that Casemiro opener.

"More or less, I watched the last game, it was one of the first ones here that we won, we were so lucky in that game. I watched against Porto, I watched against [AFC] Bournemouth, the style of play is similar, with different characteristics," he said on Forest.

"I watched one game that we didn't pre-season with Sporting CP, so to try to understand how he played in that game. It's similar, he can change some characteristics of the players with the talent that they have, especially with Gibbs-White, Anderson, Hudson-Odoi, very good players.
"So we need to be prepared for a different game against Brighton. We had space to play. We're not going to have that space.

"You need to understand that we're not being the same team. away and at home, so we need to improve the way we control the environment. Every tackle is a big moment for the opponent's fans, so we need to play better away.
"We are prepared for a very tough match."

headline: Man Utd boss Ruben Amorim makes feelings clear on Liverpool with blunt statement
body: Manchester United manager Ruben Amorim has insisted he won’t judge his side’s progress against Liverpool, despite overtaking their rivals. United went into the weekend one point better off than Liverpool, who are reeling after four straight Premier League defeats.

Amorim is enjoying the best spell of his United career, with three straight league wins coming as they head to Nottingham Forest on Saturday afternoon. United have seen off Sunderland, Liverpool and Brighton in recent weeks, allowing Amorim some positivity as he reaches a year in charge.

By contrast, Liverpool are enduring their worst spell of the Arne Slot era, with six defeats in seven games across all competitions. Slot is under huge pressure going into their 8pm kick-off against Aston Villa on Saturday evening.
But speaking ahead of the Forest game, Amorim made his feelings clear on United’s bitter rivals. “I could not care less about being in front of Liverpool,” he told beinSPORTS.

“I know [the fans might care] but it’s not my way of seeing things, I just want to win every game and to finish top of the league. I want to be in the position to be champions of the Premier League, so I don’t care about the moment in the table.

“I remember people said I was naive to talk about winning the Premier League. The goal of this board, of the owners, the staff, is winning the Premier League, that doesn’t change. I don’t know how long it’s going to take.

“So we never change our narrative. We never change because we are winning now, we are going to change what we want to do. And when we were losing we said all of the same things. We want to win the Premier League, that is our goal. Let’s see how long it is going to take.”

Asked to reflect on a year in charge in his pre-match press conference, Amorim said: “It was a journey. A big journey. It was tough. It was really tough, good moments, bad moments. I learned a lot, that is really important.

“I found out that even in my lower moments, I can stick with the things I believe and that is a good thing for anyone, to understand that. Today, the answer is different from three weeks ago. So, it’s important to understand that. It’s one of the biggest honours of my life to be here and I want to continue here for many years.”

headline: Matheus Cunha faces new Man Utd challenge after Sir Alex Ferguson claim made
body: Ex-Manchester United coach Rene Meulensteen has lauded the impact of £62.5m summer signing Matheus Cunha, but also challenged him to maintain his form. Cunha, who was signed from Wolves during the summer transfer window, has been a key addition to Ruben Amorim's squad, scoring once since his move and becoming a regular starter under Amorim.
The Brazilian netted his first goal for United during their 4-2 victory over Brighton last weekend. Despite not yet registering an assist, he has received high praise for his start at Old Trafford.

Meulensteen, who served as Sir Alex Ferguson's assistant manager during several Premier League title-winning campaigns, has been impressed with Cunha - but believes the next challenge for the player is to reach the same levels as those big names who shone under Ferguson.
"I was very positive about United signing Matheus Cunha. He's a great player," Meulensteen said in an interview with Compare.bet.
"I think he also has all the mental attributes to play for a club like Manchester United. He's got that aura.
"He wants the ball. You can give him the ball and it's hard to get it off him.

"He has raised the ceiling of this United squad and that will rub off on other players because when they see that Cunha, he's a player, and [Bryan] Mbeumo is a player, too, it lifts everyone to push their own games.

"I still find it a shame seeing Cunha and Mbeumo together, with Bruno Fernandes having to play that deeper role, because if you could have Bruno in a more advanced position where he can really roam around as we are used to, there are even more goals there playing with Cunha, Mbeumo and [Benjamin] Sesko - without a shadow of doubt.
"The challenge now for Cunha is making sure that he shows that consistency that Manchester United need now, week-in and week-out.
"That's what made United great under Sir Alex Ferguson. We had a good squad, we had good players, we had balance in the squad, it was the performance.

"They were so consistent, no matter who we played in the Premier League, in the FA Cup or any other cups or Champions League, the players performed. That is what United need to get back to - starting with Nottingham Forest and Spurs."

Cunha's next chance to impress for United will be during their Premier League clash against Nottingham Forest on Saturday afternoon. United go into the game against Forest on the back of three consecutive wins in the top flight which has seen them climb up to sixth place in the overall standings.

headline: Nani makes 'happy' Marcus Rashford claim that will raise eyebrows at Man Utd
body: Manchester United legend Nani has revealed his delight at watching Marcus Rashford flourish - even though it's happening away from Old Trafford at Barcelona.

After a troubled period under Ruben Amorim before departing the Red Devils, Rashford has been brilliant on loan at the Catalan giants - enjoying a complete change of scenery. The 28-year-old has netted five goals and provided seven assists across 13 outings in all competitions so far.

While making an instant impact, Rashford has, previously, suffered poor patches of form and became embroiled in disciplinary woes at United even before Amorim's arrival at the club. The manager ultimately decided he needed to move him on this summer.

Meanwhile, the Red Devils have endured another testing start to this season, despite their recent upturn in form. Nani's joy at witnessing Rashford's revival since departing United might well surprise some, though.

Obviously, United would have much rather witnessed him recapture his finest form at M16 instead of excelling at a European competitor. Nevertheless, Nani confessed he's happy to witness the England player returning to his peak.

"Marcus Rashford entertained Man Utd fans for many years and he's a great player - scoring beautiful goals at Old Trafford," he told Covers.com. "I don't know what happened with him at the club and, unfortunately, he's no longer part of the team.

"However, we're always happy for those who start at our club, to see them shining all over the world, especially if he's playing for Barcelona. It's a big club with a lot of talent and, if he stands up there, shows his quality and scores goals, we'll always be happy."

However, Amorim will also be aware that it's in United's best interests for Rashford to maintain his best form and deliver top-notch performances in La Liga. Barcelona are tipped to make his move permanent - if he maintains his impressive form this season.
Rashford has a £30m buy option in his contract. Barcelona, though, might aim to negotiate a slightly lower price.

headline: Alan Shearer makes 'too early' Man Utd claim after rivals' star breaks ranks on Ruben Amorim
body: Pundit and former England star Alan Shearer believes it is premature to talk about Manchester United as contenders to qualify for the Champions League. Ruben Amorim's side have a chance to end the weekend in the top four if they beat Nottingham Forest to make it four wins on the spin.

The pressure was on Amorim ahead of a home meeting with Sunderland in October. They won that game, and followed it up with victories over Liverpool and Brighton as the new-look front three of Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo and Benjamin Sesko started to click.

Next up for United is a trip to the City Ground and now it's his opposite number Sean Dyche who is up against it. "It was a poor result for Sean Dyche against Bournemouth, especially after doing so well in Europe. It will be a rocking atmosphere at Forest, as always when Man United come to town," Shearer told Betfair.

"United are looking for results to keep the good run going and they’ve had a week off due to being knocked out of the Carabao Cup. I think Forest will get something out of the game, but I'm not sure they'll win, so I'm going to say a draw.

"I think it’s too early to say they’re the real deal and that United can finish in the top four or five. If they can continue this in a month's time, I might change my mind, but let’s see what the next couple of weeks bring, and then we can judge whether they’re certainly improving."

Shearer's comments come as Forest star Morgan Gibbs-White made the unusual move of publicly showing his delight in United's persistence and turnaround. "It’s been incredible to see, obviously they’ve been going through a tough time in the past couple of years," the England international told Stan Sport (via Goal).

"But they’ve stuck with the gaffer [Amorim] and the past four or five games, you’re really starting to see how Man United should be playing, that grit and that determination to want to play for the badge. I feel like it’s been incredible to see, it’s something I feel like the league has missed."

“They are beginning to turn things around, it seems, but we have to safeguard against that," Dyche said of United. "There are subtle changes in the way they’re playing, and they have delivered performances that can win. We’ve got to be aware of that, but equally – if you look at our performance against Porto – that was a performance that we think would win against a lot of teams.

“We need to find our own freedom to it, especially here at the City Ground, where they’re always in good voice, but against the bigger names, on paper. We think we can get that energy between us and that front-foot thinking from the stands, which the players will buzz off.”

headline: Paul Scholes' daughter drops touching message to Man Utd hero over her autistic brother
body: Paul Scholes' daughter, Alicia, has emotionally shown her own support for her dad after he bravely opened up about caring for his autistic son Aiden. The Manchester United icon revealed he stepped away from live TV work this season to focus on caring for and spending more time with his 20-year-old autistic son.
"I made a decision this year because of Aiden, obviously due to his special needs you might know about," Scholes told the Stick to Football podcast.
"All the work I do now is just around his routines because he has quite a strict routine every single day, so I just decided everything I'm going to do it is around Aiden.
"We always do the same things with him as he doesn't know what day of the week it is or time. But he'll know from what we're doing what day it is."

Scholes revealed he and wife Claire have split up, but they continue to devote themselves to their three children. Discussing Aiden's routine, he added: "I pick him up every Tuesday from his daycare and we go swimming. Loves swimming then we get his pizza on the way home. Thursday pick him up, go for something to eat, go home. Sunday, I pick him up from Claire's house and we go to Tesco where he buys a trolley full of chocolate.
"So, he doesn't know what day or time it is, but he knows from what we're doing what day it is. He'll be 21 in December."

Alicia has subsequently taken to Instagram to praise her dad's courage in speaking about her brother. She wrote: "I’ve never known anyone hate talking about themselves more than you! I can only imagine how hard it was to speak about Aidie and the reality of a very very hard situation.
"My whole life your priority has always been being my dad, and growing up and realising how hard you had to work everyday alongside that is something I can’t even comprehend.

"To achieve all you did takes so much sacrifice and hard work and somehow I still had you to take me to school every morning and be there at the end of each day, so present in every aspect of my life! If anyone met you they wouldn’t have a clue the life you’ve lived, they’d just see a genuinely kind, polite, caring person

"You don’t care about people who don’t matter, and out of everything that is the most valuable thing i have learnt from you. The thing I am proudest of is being your daughter, you are the best role model and father figure I could ever have, and you do it so effortlessly.
"Anyway well done on this episode dad it was amazing and if Aidie could tell you himself he would say you really are the best dad in the world, we love you millions."
The post received multiple replies, including one from United legend David Beckham, who wrote: "Perfect words for your amazing dad."
In addition to Alicia and Aiden, Scholes has another son named Arron.
Alicia is a netball player who plays as a wing attack and centre. She joined London Pulse in 2021 and helped the club win the Netball Super Cup in July 2025, the first in their history.

headline: Man Utd held secret talks with two other managers before Ruben Amorim appointment
body: Manchester United head coach Ruben Amorim wasn't the only contender to replace Erik ten Hag in 2024. United also explored moves for Thomas Tuchel and Roberto De Zerbi several months before landing the Portuguese, it has been claimed.

Ten Hag's position was under threat towards the end of the 2023/24 season, with the Premier League side considering their options after some concerning results and performances. After winning the FA Cup final, though, the Dutchman was given a stay of execution.

By the time Ten Hag eventually lost his job in October last year, De Zerbi and Tuchel had already found employment elsewhere. Former Brighton boss De Zerbi took over at Marseille shortly after leaving the Amex Stadium while Tuchel agreed terms with England in the autumn and ultimately took charge in January 2025.

According to The Athletic, United were still considering Tuchel a fortnight after their cup final win. The German met with United chiefs in Monaco but didn't reach an agreement and indeed is said to have not been prepared to return to football so soon after leaving Bayern Munich.
De Zerbi's talks, meanwhile, were reportedly halted after the Italian rejected an initial offer from United. An improved offer didn't arrive, and the 46-year-old is now in charge at Marseille.

Ultimately, Ten Hag was backed in the transfer market to the tune of around £200million as United looked to turn things around under the ex-Ajax boss. He only lasted a few months, picking up 11 points from nine league games to leave United 14th in the table.

Results picked up under caretaker boss Ruud van Nistelrooy but Amorim was unable to inspire a full recovery in the league. He led the team to a Europa League final - and within 90 minutes of a trophy and a Champions League spot - but an eight-game winless run in April and May brought a 15th-place finish.

United made a slow start in Amorim's first full season but things have gradually picked up. Three wins on the spin have seen the Red Devils climb a congested table to sit in sixth place ahead of Saturday's meeting with Nottingham Forest.

“During my career as a manager, most of the time I was winning,” Amorim told MUTV as he brought up a year in charge. “When you are winning, you can say that you have convictions and you are loyal to your ideas, but you learn when you lose, when you are under pressure and I learned that when I’m under pressure, I’m stronger on my ideas and I keep with my ideas.

“Of course, it’s really important to feel the support of everyone in the club, especially the fans that help you, to give you that confidence to continue on your path, but that was the biggest learning point: when I’m under pressure, I can stick with my plan.”

headline: Bruno Fernandes makes Marcus Rashford feelings clear as Man Utd star sends message
body: Bruno Fernandes was among multiple Manchester United players who wished Marcus Rashford a happy birthday on social media and showed he still has strong affection for the academy graduate. Rashford celebrated turning 28 on Halloween, just two days before Barcelona take on Elche and the day before Manchester United's trip to Nottingham Forest.

Current and former team-mates took to social media to send their well-wishes, and Fernandes was among the first to post, sharing a selfie of the pair on his Instagram story. He tagged Rashford, writing: "Happy birthday broski. Enjoy your day as you deserve."
Rashford reshared it to his own story, adding: "love brother." Barcelona colleague Roony Bardghji also posted to his story: "Happy birthday my bro," whilst tagging Rashford.
Former United academy graduate and close friend RoShaun Williams shared a throwback team photograph from their youth, writing: "Happy birthday to the right hand." Rashford responded: "From early."

He then uploaded a picture of himself standing beside balloons with a cake placed on the table in front of him. Upon closer examination, the cake shows the reverse of Barcelona's home kit, displaying his squad number 14.
"Chapter 28 The Resurrection," he wrote beneath the post. David de Gea became one of the first ex-teammates to respond, posting a red heart emoji alongside a partying face emoji.
Harry Maguire quickly followed, commenting: "Happy birthday mate." Former United academy prospect DJ Buffonge added: "More life, more blessings."
Another former academy graduate, Devonte Redmond, wrote: "Happy birthday bro, showed us all impossible is nothing! Keep striving."

Meanwhile, Rashford received birthday wishes from Coleen Rooney, who commented: "Happy birthday - have the best time celebrating xx." His brother, Dwaine Maynard, also left a message, writing: "Mum is over for your game on Sunday. A win and a goal would be nice."
Former Manchester United teammate Jesse Lingard chimed in with: "Happy birthday, brother."
Ex-Aston Villa colleagues Ian Maatsen and Leon Bailey joined the celebrations too - "Happy birthday bro," Maatsen posted, whilst Bailey added: "More life and blessings my boy."

headline: Ruben Amorim sent Man Utd transfer demand amid £27m Tottenham hijack chance
body: Manchester United legend Nani has called on his former club to make a move for midfielder Joao Palhinha - who the Red Devils were desperate to land last year.

United attempted to secure the Portuguese star's signature, but he eventually sealed a £47.4million switch from Fulham to Bayern Munich. Yet, he failed to nail down a regular spot under Vincent Kompany and was shipped out on loan to Tottenham this summer - with Spurs holding a £27million option to make the deal permanent.

"Joao Palhinha is a great player. I played with him at Sporting, where he was growing and learning a lot," the former Red Devils' winger revealed to Covers.com. "After a few years, he became one of the best players in his position.

"He's very strong and talented at winning and recovering the ball, and also tackling. He's also improved his forward play, scoring goals, connecting with the team, and moving forward with the ball. He's become a complete player in his position."

With doubts over whether Tottenham, or not, will trigger their buy-out clause to secure his services permanently next summer, Nani has urged United to try and scupper any possible agreement between the north London outfit and Bayern.

"I think he's a great player and can do really well for Tottenham. He had an opportunity with Bayern and we're not sure what will happen next season, but he's a player who can play for any team in the world," he added.

"He just needs to be consistent and fit, as injuries cause problems. I trust he will have a fantastic career. He's a player with energy, with power to recover balls and to fight, and that is something that fits into Man Utd's DNA.

"Having players who are able to fight on the field, like to recover the ball and challenge opponents to help the team win games. You can't give your opponents any time in the Premier League, and he has all the energy and physical abilities to be such an asset for anyone."
Following their failure to land Palhinha, United eventually brought in Manuel Ugarte from Sporting CP during the same window that saw Palhinha finally secure his desired switch to Munich.

headline: Is Nottingham Forest vs Man Utd on TV? Live stream details, kick-off time and team news
body: Manchester United travel to the City Ground in high spirits after securing three consecutive victories under Ruben Amorim - a first in the Portuguese manager's tenure. Saturday marks Amorim's one-year anniversary at Old Trafford and he'll be eager to celebrate the occasion by guiding United to a fourth straight win - something the club hasn't achieved in nearly two years.

Nottingham Forest, by contrast, are in search of stability after a turbulent start to the season. Sean Dyche is already the club's third manager of the campaign, having replaced Ange Postecoglou last month - just 39 days after Postecoglou himself succeeded Nuno Espirito Santo.

An emphatic 2-0 Europa League win over Porto last week suggested the tide could be turning, but Forest were brought back down to earth a few days later by Bournemouth, who beat them by the same scoreline. Three points against United would certainly be a mood-lifter, but that'll be easier said than done.

The visitors arrive in fine form, buoyed by victories over Sunderland, Liverpool and Brighton in the past month. Amorim's side are beginning to look far more cohesive and confident in possession, with his philosophy clearly starting to take hold.
Nottingham Forest's clash against Manchester United takes place on Saturday, November 1. The game will be held at Forest's home stadium, the City Ground, with kick-off at 3pm UK time.
No. The match will not be broadcast on live TV due to the UK's 3pm blackout rule. Instead, fans can follow the action live commentary on BBC Radio 5 Live.
United supporters can tune in to MUTV, where live commentary and analysis will be provided. Meanwhile, highlights of the match will be shown on Match of the Day on Saturday evening.
Fans outside of the UK won't have to wait with the blackout rule not applying around the world. Supporters in the United States, for example, will be able to live stream the action via Peacock.

Harry Maguire was the only notable absentee - aside from long-term injury victim Lisandro Martinez - for last weekend's win over Brighton. The England international could return to the squad against Forest, though United are unlikely to risk rushing him back.

After picking up a knock last week, Mason Mount was left on the bench against Brighton. He is, however, expected to be fully fit for the Forest game. Luke Shaw was also a doubt heading into the clash against the Seagulls after coming down ill, yet managed to play through it.
Amorim did, however, admit the defender was "suffering" during the game. These concerns aside, the United boss is likely to have close to a full-strength squad at his disposal.

Chris Wood is yet to feature under Dyche after sustaining an injury last month, though the New Zealand striker could return to contention this weekend. However, Forest may opt against rushing him back into action.

Elsewhere, Dyche will be without Ola Aina, who remains sidelined with a thigh problem, while Dilane Bakwa is also unavailable. Oleksandr Zinchenko faces a late fitness test, with his involvement still in doubt.

Forest have a strong recent record against United, having won three of their last four meetings between the two sides. They completed the double over Amorim's team last season, winning 1-0 at the City Ground in April and 3-2 at Old Trafford the previous December.

United's last Premier League triumph over Forest came back in August 2023. Before that, the Red Devils had enjoyed a dominant run of 10 consecutive victories over the East Midlands outfit, a streak that stretched all the way back to 1996.

headline: Liverpool and Man Utd receive message from £75m transfer target – 'I'm glad'
body: Bournemouth forward Antonine Semenyo has spoken openly about his future after being linked with moves to Liverpool and Manchester United. The Ghana international is enjoying a stellar start to the season, scoring six goals and registering three assists in nine league appearances.

Semenyo stepped up for Bournemouth last term after Dominic Solanke was sold to Tottenham Hotspur. His performances prompted interest from other Premier League clubs during the summer transfer window, with Semenyo reportedly meeting up with United boss Ruben Amorim at the end of last season.

The Bournemouth forward has also been touted as a future replacement for Mohamed Salah at Liverpool. However, despite seeing several of his Bournemouth team-mates move on, Semenyo chose to extend his contract until 2030.

His new deal is claimed to include a release clause and although the figure is unknown, it is said that the Cherries value Semenyo at £75million. While many players might choose not to discuss their future, Semenyo has admitted he is aware of the transfer speculation surrounding him, but is happy with his decision to stay with Bournemouth in the summer.
"I'm enjoying my football here. If I'm not scoring goals, all of that goes away. I try to stay present, do the best I can for the team, score goals and whatever happens in the future happens.

"When they (his former team-mates) all left [in the summer], there was a lot of interest and back and forth with the club. But I knew in my head that the manager's got something up his sleeve this year. How we finished off the season last year was so good and we could continue, especially with the players we've bought in as well.
"I wasn't too sure at the start but we've kicked on like a house on fire. I'm glad I committed to staying here because I'm enjoying every moment."

There were initial doubts about how Bournemouth would fare this term after losing several key players in the summer. Centre-backs Dean Huijsen and Illia Zabarnyi were sold to Real Madrid and PSG, respectively, while Liverpool signed left-back Milos Kerkez.

Bournemouth also sanctioned Dango Ouattara’s permanent move to Brentford and were forced to find a new goalkeeper after previous Chelsea loanee Kepa Arrizabalaga joined Arsenal. However, Andoni Iraola’s side have seemingly been unfazed by the summer overhaul.

Ahead of the weekend’s fixtures, Bournemouth sit second in the league table with 18 points after nine games. Iraola will be eager for Semenyo and his other players to continue their excellent form as they prepare for a tough clash away at Manchester City on Sunday.

headline: New Cristiano Ronaldo bombshells teased that could be as wild as Man Utd interview
body: Piers Morgan has revealed that Cristiano Ronaldo's most intimate and candid interview to date will air next week. Morgan says he and Ronaldo recently met in Saudi Arabia for an 80-minute discussion.

Their previous sit-down, three years ago, led to Manchester United and the player mutually agreeing to end his contract during the mid-season World Cup in Qatar. That exit allowed Saudi Pro League club Al Nassr to sign Ronaldo, where he continues playing out his career to this day.
Morgan has described their most recent exchange as "amazingly heartfelt, honest, warm and often hilarious". Morgan has teased the interview on his Instagram account.

"So many people asking me about my new interview with Cristiano Ronaldo," the caption of his post reads. "What does he say? How personal does he get? Is it very revealing? Was anything off limits? To which the answers are: a) A lot, b) VERY, c) Yes, and d) No."

"I spent 80 minutes chatting to the (goat emoji) of football at his home in Saudi Arabia, and it was an amazingly heartfelt, honest, warm and often hilarious conversation. It airs next week on Piers Morgan Uncensored. You won't want to miss this!"

Morgan also shared on X: "UPDATE: The announcement of my new Ronaldo interview has now been viewed 51 million times on our combined X and Insta accounts. In just 24 hours...! This is why he's the (goat emoji)." Morgan's announcement post has just over 344,000 views at the time of writing.

Ronaldo last commented on United towards the end of last year. "I said this one and a half years ago, and I will continue to say it: The problem is not the coaches," he said at the Globe Soccer Awards in Dubai.
"It's like an aquarium. If you have the fish inside and he's sick and you take him out and you fix the problem and you put him again in an aquarium, they will be sick again.
"The problem of Manchester United is the same. The problem is not always the coach. It's much more than that.
"If I were the owner of the club, I would make things clear and adjust what I think is bad there."

headline: Bruno Fernandes has his plea answered after moaning at Man Utd team-mates
body: The Manchester United squad answering Bruno Fernandes' demand for a tactical change has proved crucial in sparking their current winning streak. Ruben Amorim's team have won their previous three league games, with United hoping to make it four victories on the bounce in their visit to Nottingham Forest on Saturday.

While Amorim recently orchestrated a stunning 2-1 victory over Liverpool at Anfield, the Red Devils' subsequent 4-2 home triumph against Brighton last weekend was perhaps even more important. Goals from Matheus Cunha, Casemiro and a Bryan Mbeumo double helped create the belief that United's promising form might be more than a brief hot streak.

United boss Amorim has faced fierce criticism during his reign for his unwavering commitment to his 3-4-3 system. Many pundits and United supporters previously argued that the team were poorly suited to the formation.

However, Fernandes predicted how United could transform their fortunes following the club's 3-0 derby defeat to Manchester City in September. The United captain emphasised that for the side to flourish, more players needed to drop into midfield.

The midfield partnership of Fernandes and Casemiro was frequently overwhelmed during the opening weeks of the campaign before United started to follow their skipper's advice. Fernandes highlighted the issue when comparing United's shortcomings to City's flurry of midfielders.
"If you look at City, they had Rodri, Tiji [Reijnders], Bernardo [Silva] coming in, [Phil] Foden. They make basically a midfield four against a two.

"So you need the ones in behind you to jump, like Luke [Shaw] was doing very well on Tiji. We did it in the first game against Arsenal, that's why they didn't play. They couldn't find the spaces to play.

"That's what makes the spaces very narrow to play against a team that is very aggressive to play on the front foot. If you're not brave enough to do that, they will find the spaces to play because we're playing against a top opponent."

It appears the United squad have taken Fernandes' request on board. Luke Shaw, in particular, received praise for his recent display against Brighton, at times advancing from his role in the back three into the midfield.

The extra backing for Fernandes and Casemiro gave United greater stability, enabling the team to thrive. Meanwhile, Shaw claimed an assist for Casemiro's deflected strike against Brighton after challenging for possession in midfield.

"What Man United have been crying out for is if you're going to play that system, be brave," former City defender Micah Richards said on The Rest Is Football podcast. Luke Shaw was very brave the way he stepped in, and then they go and get the goal.

"If you look at the positioning yesterday of Cunha, Cunha was filling in in that midfield role." He continued: "That's the first time I've been convinced that [United] know exactly what their roles are. Now the challenge is consistency."

The tactical flexibility shown by both Shaw and Cunha gave United the numerical advantage that Fernandes believed was lacking in the match against City. A few weeks later, United's response to their captain's plea for more support has been key to their winning streak.

headline: Paul Pogba dealt new blow as ex-Man Utd star has comeback delayed again
body: Monaco head coach Sebastien Pocognoli has confirmed Paul Pogba will have to wait even longer to make his Monaco debut. Pogba, 32, penned a two-year deal with the Ligue 1 club this summer following seven-and-a-half months without a team.

The former Manchester United midfielder departed Juventus in mid-November after mutually agreeing to terminate his contract in Turin. That move came six weeks before Pogba could return to training following his doping suspension, which Pogba claims was because of a prescribed nutritional supplement.
His four-year ban began in September 2023, but after an appeal, Pogba had it halved to 18 months. He has been cleared to play since March.
Monaco placed the player on a three-month fitness programme to get him back to full sharpness. A comeback to the matchday squad was due to happen in October.

There were expectations that Monaco would have him available for their first fixture following the international break. That did not happen, though, as an injury delayed that comeback by a further two weeks.
Pocognoli had hinted it might happen this weekend against Paris FC. "It is possible that he will be in the squad, yes," the Monaco head coach said.
"Paul still has a training session on Thursday, and if he is feeling good, we could see him again. And he would be within the process that we fixed."
Nevertheless, the midfielder is not in good shape after that session, having sustained an ankle injury. "We are awaiting confirmation of the severity of the injury," Pocognoli said.
"The idea is that he can be available after the international break; that is the plan that we are following. We are all disappointed."
Monaco's first fixture following their fortnight off sees them travel to Stade Rennais. They then face Pafos in the Champions League before hosting Paris Saint-Germain to complete a three-game week.

headline: RAILSTON: Amad reaction after Manchester United vs Nottingham Forest spoke volumes
body: Ruben Amorim has already admitted that Manchester United will struggle when Amad goes to the Africa Cup of Nations. United wouldn't have salvaged a point against Nottingham Forest without the Ivory Coast international.

Amad's stunning volley from the edge of the box will be prominent in this season's highlights reel. The 23-year-old looked disappointed when the full-time whistle went, despite scoring a stunner. The away end chanted "we love United, we do" after a spirited fight to avoid defeat.
Amorim named an unchanged team for the first time in the Premier League. Amorim has previously chopped and changed, but rewarded the players who delivered against Brighton.
United had lost their last two away league games against Nottingham Forest. Anthony Elanga scored in a 1-0 Forest win in April when Amorim desperately resorted to throwing Harry Maguire up front.
United have been the leading goalscorers in the Premier League since the victory against Burnley at the end of September so Maguire was not required as an auxiliary forward again.
Forest sacked Nuno Espirito Santo just three games into the campaign. Ange Postecoglou was appointed as his successor and lasted just 39 days in charge after failing to win any of his eight games.
Sean Dyche has a reputation for rescuing sinking ships. Dyche appears to be a sensible appointment and he urged their fans to create an intimidating atmosphere against United in his programme notes.
There was a rousing rendition of 'Mull of Kintyre' as the players prepared for kick-off. United fans unfurled a Brazil flag in the away section following Matheus Cunha's first goal for the club.
Diogo Dalot received an earful from Amorim throughout the opening exchanges. The United boss wanted him to burst forward quicker when he received the ball and constantly encouraged him down the left.
Amorim praised Forest midfielder Elliot Anderson before the game and the midfielder whipped up the home crowd after a shot from Callum Hudson-Odoi was almost sent into the River Trent.

Anderson has been linked with a move to Old Trafford, but he is exactly what his shirt number suggests: a No.8. United do not need a player of that profile and should focus on other targets next summer.

United created chances in the first half and Benjamin Sesko looked lively, although he scuffed a shot in the box and dragged an effort wide of the post after skilfully fashioning a yard of space for himself.
Amad should have done better when he guided a shot at Matz Sels. Amorim couldn't stand still on the touchline, clearly wanting more cutting edge from his players after a mixed start.
United were ahead shortly after following a stroke of good fortune, scoring from a corner when the ball didn't look to have gone out of play for the set piece to be awarded.
Fernandes was responsible for the delivery and briefly congratulated Casemiro before being summoned to the touchline to receive tactical instructions from Amorim.
There were loud boos for referee Darren England when he returned to the dressing room for the interval, the Forest fans feeling aggrieved about the decision to award a corner.
The chatter among the home supporters on the concourse on the way to the press room was about the dubious decision. The chatter in the away section was probably about how important Casemiro is again.
The 33-year-old has enjoyed an unlikely resurgence this year and he was serenaded after opening the scoring. "Du, du, du, du, Casemiro," sang the 3,000 Mancunians housed in the Bridgford Stand.

The Forest fans who were complaining were on their feet twice just six minutes into the second half. The disadvantages of playing Amad at right wing-back were highlighted when Morgan Gibbs-White won their aerial mismatch to score a header. Then Forest scored again through Nicola Savona.
United were punished by another ball into the box. Dyche was beaming from the dug-out. He enjoyed success at Burnley and Everton by setting up his teams to score similar aerial goals.
"Lino, what's the score?," chirped the Brian Clough Stand. Forest had last clinched a league win against Brentford in August and their fans sensed the first big result of Dyche's tenure.
The draw is a reminder that there is more work for Amorim to do. The 40-year-old enjoyed an October to remember, but he must secure successive wins again during the winter.

Amorim will be pleased with the spirit shown after falling behind, particularly from Amad after losing the battle with Gibbs-White for his goal. Amad is the kind of character that Amorim wants in the dressing room.
And it helps that he's also a very good footballer.

headline: RAILSTON: Ruben Amorim gives one-word answer about Manchester United progress after Nottingham Forest draw
body: Ruben Amorim believes Manchester United would have lost against Nottingham Forest if the game had been played last season.
United opened the scoring at the City Ground thanks to a header from Casemiro, but the match was turned on its head almost immediately after play resumed for the second half.
Morgan Gibbs-White levelled the scores in the 48th minute and Nicolo Savona made it 2-1 just two minutes later.
Forest fans sensed their first win in the league since August, but Amad popped up with nine minutes remaining to score a stunning goal which ensured the points were shared.
Amorim was asked whether United would have lost the fixture last season and responded: "Yeah."
He paused before adding: "By more goals [they would have lost]. That is my feeling."
When asked why, Amorim said: "It's the confidence, of course, it's completely different. We came from three good games and we have a different confidence. We understand each other better.

"We talk more about this, that football is like this, and we proved it this year. We can have bad moments, but suddenly we have three good games. So football is like that. And the game is like that also.

"We had good moments, we score, you can sense we are in control of the game when the first half finished. We started the second half, we suffer, disconnect for five minutes and that's enough in the Premier League, but we managed to recover from that, which is a good feeling."

Discussing his thoughts on the game in further detail, Amorim said: "We lost control of the game for five minutes and paid the price. We did some things well. Our level of energy dropped a little bit.

"And when our energy drops a little bit, you can feel it. We can play well, but it's not full power. But my feeling is that the players tried, really tried. They tried during the week and tried again today.

"In the past, if we had this kind of bad five minutes and we suffer two goals, we didn't recover. Today is a different feeling and you can sense we could win this game, but we weren't going to lose, and that's sometimes the feeling a big team sometimes has.
"We had the opportunity to win in the end, but we drew. We dropped two points. I think last year we suffered a lot. We want to win games and overcome these moments, but now they know how to do it.
"We just need to be inside of the game until the final 10 minutes of the game. That is part of football. In the past, we could have lost everything in the positions and the way we play the game.
"I think we are improving in that aspect. Again, we did some things right, but we also have potential to play so much better, which is the goal."

body: Manchester United manager Ruben Amorim has explained his team selection ahead of today's Premier League game against Nottingham Forest.
Amorim has named an unchanged starting XI for the clash at City Ground, the first time he has done so since he was appointed United manager exactly a year ago today.

Harry Maguire has come back into the squad having missed last weekend's win over Brighton through injury. The England international has been named on the bench with Leny Yoro keeping his place alongside Matthijs de Ligt and Luke Shaw.

"We are confident as a team and a club. Our fans have more confidence but we need to forget what we did in the past, we need to do it all over again against a very tough opponent and a manager who has a huge impact when he changes teams.

"We are playing for Manchester United, we are in a good moment so let's hold to that. We want to win but it's what we want to do in the game. We are learning from our mistakes so we need to maintain our level."
United enter today's game in sixth position in the table with Forest languishing in the drop zone.

headline: RAILSTON: From struggles to future plans to the best decision of his life - Ruben Amorim on one year at Man United
body: Ruben Amorim warned that the storm was coming after his Manchester United appointment, but the dark clouds have lifted above Old Trafford and brighter days seem to be ahead.

United have won three Premier League games on the bounce and Amorim has been nominated for October's manager of the month award. The victory against Liverpool at Anfield felt like it could be a tenure-defining result, and United built on that performance by securing three points against Brighton last weekend.
It's the one-year anniversary of Amorim's appointment from Sporting Lisbon today, and the 40-year-old will try to mark the occasion by winning away against Nottingham Forest.

Amorim spoke to reporters at Carrington on Thursday and discussed his first 12 months in Manchester. "We need to think positively, but we also need to be prepared that football is like this," he said when asked whether the storm he predicted would come had passed.
"And we are not that team that I can say to you, now we can lose here or there, but we are going to maintain. I trust my players more, I think they trust me more. That will come with wins.

"You can sense that, because everyone now is saying that, 'Oh, connected they are, and they believe in the manager'. It's about winning games, it didn't change a lot, because against Arsenal I saw the same thing.

"So I don't know. I think that we are in a better place, but it's also really good to be always without feeling and prepared that something can change. If we have that feeling, we will be more... We will pay attention to the details, we will maintain that course of our path. I can say that we are a better team in this moment."

When asked whether there had been any moments when he doubted he would last a year in the job, Amorim said: "It's hard to say that. Sometimes in some moments... I know that you are going to write [laughs]... But there were some moments that were tough to deal with, to lose so many games, that was so hard for me, because this is Manchester United.
"The position that we had in the last year, putting all the attention on Europa League and not winning, that was massive. So I had some moments that I struggled a lot.

"And I was thinking that maybe it's not meant to be. Today is the opposite. So you can write this one. Today I feel that, and I know that, that was the best decision in my life, and I want to be here."

Amorim has remained upbeat even during the tough moments. "It's also my character, and then sometimes it's also... I know that a lot of people want to see me arriving here with that face that I'm suffering, and I like to do the opposite, sometimes I think about that," he said.

"But it's the way of seeing things. So I said, since the first moment, this will not change who I am, and I'm like that, and I live my life like this, and I know that football will change in some moment, and now we are in a good moment, but I'm always with that feeling here that something can change.

"So I try to balance my life, but you can say that I laugh a lot, but you also can say that I'm always like [lowers his head] this on the bench, and like this [pretends to be exasperated], so I just live with emotions, and I follow my team. If my team is playing well and running a lot, I will be a happy man."
Amorim is wedded to his 3-4-3 formation and has refused to tweak his system, despite intense scrutiny. Is he tempted to turn around and say 'I told you so' after an excellent October?

"No, because I know that in two weeks this could change again," he said. "And you will say, 'No, no, we were right,' so it's like a crazy conversation. I just have a clear idea how I want to do things, I'm always saying the same thing.

"For me, it's a 3-4-3 that we are going to change against different opponents, so I just need time, like every manager. Maybe my way of doing things is going to take more time, for people to start seeing things.

"And that manager that arrives in one club, in the next four games they can win three and lose one, but then there's also luck in the games, again, we had some luck against Liverpool, and all the narrative changed because of that, so I understand football, I just do what I feel is the best thing for the team and for the club."

Amorim added on his formation: "I think the rotation of the team is easier for me, because I spend so much time thinking about that. I don't see it as a 3-4-3, I see it at the beginning, at the base of the idea of 3-4-3.
"Because I spend a lot of time playing like that, because when I start thinking about the system, nobody was playing 3-4-3, so I can understand how to rotate players, even in the way we buy players.

"If you have a clear idea how to play, it's easy for you to point, this is the guy that I want. And that can help you. When you have today is 4-3-3, and then tomorrow is 4-4-2, it's harder to make the characteristics right for the players, so I try to use all this knowledge to search for the right players."
Although Amorim discussed bringing in players for his system, he played down plans for the January transfer window. "I don't know what is going to happen," he said.
"A lot of things can happen. Even in our club, and you know that we have the World Cup, some players are not playing, they will ask to leave, so I have to manage everything.

"And then we want to bring players, everyone here, we want to bring players that we can see a big future in Manchester United. We are not just buying one guy, because now we feel in December that we need this kind of player for now. No, it's going to be... We want to buy players that we know we are not going to change a lot of times. So that is our idea.
"So I don't know what is going to happen, but of course, we think about how we can improve the team, and January, the window is open, we can do something."

United's direct approach was effective against Sunderland, Liverpool and Brighton, and Amorim was asked whether that was an example of his tactics evolving. "I also don't believe that we have a style that we have to build up always from the back," the United boss said.

"We want to build up to push the opponents to have space to score goals. If the space is there, if the numbers are there, if there is three against three in front, and I have Ben [Sesko], [Matheus] Cunha, for example, and Bryan [Mbeumo] I will put the ball in two passes, I want to score goals in two passes.

"But sometimes you have to build up. What I try to teach my players is which kind of game I need to play in this situation. That is my job, I don't want to teach my players to build up with a lot of touches and then bring it.

"If you need a lot of touches, you will understand that you need a lot of touches. If you need one, put the ball, because the fans want to see a different game. We are in England, I try to show you a little bit of English football in the past.
"It's [not] that I don't have a clear way of building up, I just look at the space, the number of players, the characteristics of my players and try to use that to win games."

Amorim urged his players to reproduce their Old Trafford performances when playing away this season. "When we play at home we are more intense, we are more focused, our fans help us a lot, when we have an opportunity you can feel the stadium helping us to control the game," he said.

"But when we play away, it's different. The fans are not there for us, against Brentford we were not so intense, our recovery was not so good, against Fulham we lost control of the game when we were winning, and we show a different team, that we are a different team playing in our home.

"So it's not a technical thing, it's not a tactical thing, we need to play a different style, we just need to be the same team, to believe in the same way that we do at home. We need to show that away."

headline: Man United great Roy Keane tipped for huge management return - 'What we want'
body: Manchester United legend Nani has shared enthusiasm at the prospect of Roy Keane taking up the reins at Celtic, following Brendan Rodgers' recent departure from the Scottish giants.
Celtic released a statement, on Monday, confirming Rodgers' resignation. It read: "Celtic Football Club can confirm that football manager Brendan Rodgers has today tendered his resignation.
"It has been accepted by the club and Brendan will now leave his role with immediate effect. The club appreciates Brendan's contribution to Celtic during his two very successful periods at the club.

"Brendan leaves Celtic with our thanks for the role he has played during a period of continued success for the club and we wish him further success in the future. The process to appoint a new permanent manager is underway and the club will update supporters further on this as soon as possible."

In the interim, Martin O'Neill and Shaun Maloney have agreed to oversee Celtic's operations while the search for a new permanent first-team manager continues. Several names, including Damien Duff, Steven Gerrard and Ange Postecoglou, have been suggested as potential successors at Celtic Park following Rodgers' exit, but Nani has also suggested that Keane should step up.

In an interview with Covers, the 38-year-old, who represented the Reds between 2007 and 2015, said: "It would be great to see Roy Keane back in management, everyone loves to see personalities like that in the game.
"He's a strong personality, confident in what he's doing and saying.

"This is what we want in football. We want people with courage to try things, prove themselves, and show other players how to do it. They can teach and help because they have the experience. So, yes, for sure, it would be very, very nice to see him back, wherever it is."

Following a distinguished playing career for Cobh Rangers, United, Nottingham Forest and Celtic, Keane stepped into management with Sunderland AFC in 2006. He guided the Black Cats to Premier League promotion in his first campaign before stepping down in 2008.

A subsequent two-year spell at Ipswich Town followed between 2009 and 2011, while he has since then taken up assistant positions with the Republic of Ireland, Aston Villa and Forest - alongside punditry and podcasting work. Nani's comments come as Celtic endure an inconsistent campaign, sitting second in the Scottish Premiership, nine points adrift of Hearts, having recorded six victories, two defeats and two draws.

With arch rivals Rangers awaiting them in Sunday's Scottish League Cup semi-final, O'Neill and Maloney will be hoping to lift morale in Parkhead before travelling to face Midtjylland in the Europa League on Thursday. Celtic's next league encounter arrives on Sunday, 9 November, when they welcome Kilmarnock to Glasgow.

Amorim's handling of Mainoo was a talking point throughout the first few weeks of the campaign, with the United boss saying that Mainoo is competing with Bruno Fernandes to start.
Mainoo has not started in the Premier League this season. The midfielder has been limited to substitute appearances and his only start came against Grimsby Town in the Carabao Cup second round.
Amorim was asked whether Champions League qualification was the target after a brilliant October and name-dropped Mainoo when discussing the importance of returning to Europe.
"No, it's not," Amorim said about Champions League qualification being the target. "We need to go to Europe, because of everything. Our club needs to be in Europe.
"It's hard to have a very, very good scout. Imagine what it's like for me to have Kobbie Mainoo with the minutes that he's playing, he needs more games for me to make a rotation.
"Because with one game it's really hard, I have to take one of the guys that is playing to put another. When you have more games, you can divide, you can manage the group in a different way.
"We are trying to use the time that we have to train to be a better team, we need to be prepared in the future to have European games. But the target doesn't change.
"We have to go to Europe. To be in the top four is really hard for our moment, but we never know, we just need to focus on winning the next one and then we will see."
Amorim was asked about keeping the players who aren't playing happy and said: "Because around the training ground, the mood seems so much brighter than it was.

"First of all, they understand, I prove that anyone can play, and everyone has to do the same things, not in the same way, but there are some things that everyone, no matter what is your name, you have to do it to play for Manchester United.
"And that can help to manage... I try to explain all the time to the players that this is... We are not just playing today, not just this year, but then the next seasons.
"So they feel that they are part of the journey, and that we are part of something more bigger than just one game or one season. So they are part of our path.
"And then I show also to them that Casemiro was not part of the starting XI, was behind, and then he fought. He won the place, and if you win the place, you will be playing.
"So I think that helped them to understand that I'm trying to be fair, and they are part of something very special that is very important to us."

headline: Man United handed instant new referee verdict after Nottingham Forest flashpoint
body: Casemiro's opening goal for Manchester United in their Premier League match with Nottingham Forest perhaps shouldn't have counted. Ruben Amorim's side dominated the opening 30 minutes and got their reward when the Brazil international headed home a Bruno Fernandes corner.

However, that set-piece was a contentious issue. Nicola Savona headed away a dangerous cross as he looked to keep the ball in, though the assistant referee - who was on the other side of the pitch - put his flag up for a corner that Casemiro subsequently scored from.
Ex-Premier League referee Mike Dean has since made his thoughts on the incident perfectly clear.

The half-time whistle at the City Ground just 10 minutes later was met by boos from the home supporters with Elliot Anderson among the players that complained to officials. United will not care very much, however, as they search a fourth consecutive victory in the Premier League.
Wins over Brighton, Liverpool and Sunderland came before the trip to Nottingham with Bryan Mbeumo, Matheus Cunha and Casemiro proving clinical in front of goal.
Only playing once every seven days has, seemingly, helped United and Amorim with another three points this afternoon likely to take them into the top-four, if only for a few hours.

Speaking on Forest, he said at a press conference: "More or less, I watched the last game, it was one of the first ones here that we won, we were so lucky in that game. I watched against Porto, I watched against Bournemouth, the style of play is similar, with different characteristics.

"I watched one game that we didn't pre-season with Sporting CP, so to try to understand how he played in that game. It's similar, he can change some characteristics of the players with the talent that they have, especially with Gibbs-White, Anderson, Hudson-Odoi, very good players.
"So we need to be prepared for a different game against Brighton. We had space to play. We are not going to have that space.

"You need to understand that we are not being the same team away and at home, so we need to improve the way we control the environment. Every tackle is a big moment for the opponent's fans, so we need to play better away.
"We are prepared for a very tough match."

headline: RAILSTON: Ruben Amorim sends message to Thomas Tuchel about Manchester United star
body: Ruben Amorim wants Luke Shaw to play himself back into the England squad, but he would not mind if the defender was overlooked if it means he stays fully fit for Manchester United.
Shaw has started every Premier League game this season and has remained injury-free.

The 30-year-old seemed to pick up a knock against Brighton, but Amorim later confirmed he was substituted during the second half because he had been suffering from a virus in the days leading up to the game.
Shaw struggled against Manchester City in the Manchester derby, but his performances have otherwise been strong and he could earn a recall to the England squad later this month.
Gareth Southgate included Shaw in his England squad for Euro 2024. The defender has not received a call-up since that tournament, but his form could be rewarded by Thomas Tuchel.
Amorim spoke at his pre-match press conference on Thursday and was asked whether he believed Shaw deserved a recall to England's squad. "It's hard, it's hard here, it's hard in Portugal," he said.
"I have the same questions about the players, it's really hard to choose the players. People point a finger at you if you are the national manager, if you choose this one or the other one.
"And England has a lot of good players, and you can choose two teams to win a World Cup, I know it's tough for you guys, it's harder than Portugal, but it's an opinion."

Amorim sympathised with the international selection process, adding: "It's the way you play, it's the way you see the opponents you have. In the next two games, it will change what kind of player you want to call up. So I think he deserves it, but also a lot of players deserve to be back.

"For me, I want him to go to the national team, but I also want Luke Shaw to train with me, recover with me, and be prepared for my game, so I'm a little bit selfish on that, so if he's not going to the national team, for me it's fine, because I can control better what he's doing."
Tuchel explained his decision to overlook Shaw during the October international break, saying: “It was a very close call. I just want him to have a little bit more minutes. He looks very fit.

"He looks very determined. I think he has the quality, the experience to play and to make us better straight away. But I want to keep him back a little bit, when he has more rhythm than he has right now."
